newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish KGHM's slow trim calms discontent-analyst.
newsitem.headline: Polish KGHM's slow trim calms discontent-analyst.

text.p: The restructuring of Polish copper giant KGHM Polska Miedz SA will sooth labour problems as it will last over three years but does not fully tackle employment issues, a leading independent analyst said.

Krzysztof Gorzedowski, former head of restructuring in a 4,000-employee coal mine in the Polish city of Walbrzych, said KGHM's three-year guarantees not to reduce orders or employment levels in firms it sheds would delay staff restructuring in often over-staffed companies.

"This type of restructuring, of great concern for workers, in my view is the correct path because it ensures social calm...but real restructuring will occur when employment structures in the carved-out firms change after three years," he told Reuters.

KGHM has 22,000 workers directly involved in copper production and a further 20,000 in auxiliary firms. Gorzedowski said the three-year protective period was long enough for the auxiliary firms, not directly involved in copper production, to change their profile and find alternative sources of income other than servicing KGHM.
"The larger auxiliary firms may have to face staff reductions, but three years is enough time to reorganise and find new markets," he said.
